summary_markdown:
# About ThousandEyes (part of Cisco)

ThousandEyes, founded in 2010, is a company that specializes in Digital Experience Assurance, providing visibility into digital experiences delivered over the Internet. In August 2020, ThousandEyes was acquired by Cisco and now operates as part of Cisco's Networking Business Group. The company offers a platform that empowers organizations to monitor and enhance digital experiences across various networks, including traditional, SD-WAN, Internet, and cloud provider networks. The platform leverages AI and extensive telemetry data to help IT teams proactively detect, diagnose, and resolve issues before they impact end-user experiences [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/senior-software-engineer-web-platform/92836).

ThousandEyes serves a B2B market, with its platform being utilized by over 100 of the Fortune 500 companies and 190 of the Global 2000. Notable customers include six of the seven top US banks and nine of the top ten global software companies [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/company/thousandeyes-part-cisco). The integration into Cisco's ecosystem allows ThousandEyes to leverage Cisco's extensive resources and market reach, although specific revenue figures for ThousandEyes post-acquisition are not disclosed.

The company's products are distributed as part of Cisco's broader technology portfolio, enhancing its capabilities in network assurance and observability. ThousandEyes is now a foundational component of Cisco's Full-Stack Observability business, which aims to provide comprehensive insights across networking and security domains [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/engineering-manager-site-reliability-engineering-fedramp/81284).

# Key Personnel

While specific key personnel for ThousandEyes are not detailed in the provided sources, it is important to note that the company is part of Cisco, which emphasizes diversity and inclusion within its workforce. Cisco encourages candidates from various backgrounds to apply, highlighting that diverse teams are better equipped to innovate and solve problems [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/senior-software-engineer-web-platform/92836).

# News

## Acquisitions and Integrations

- **August 2020**: ThousandEyes was acquired by Cisco and integrated into Cisco's Networking Business Group. This acquisition has allowed ThousandEyes to enhance its capabilities in network assurance and observability, becoming a foundational component of Cisco's Full-Stack Observability business [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/engineering-manager-site-reliability-engineering-fedramp/81284).

## Product Enhancements

- **Recent Developments**: ThousandEyes has been actively modernizing its technology stack. Recent projects include upgrading its core frontend framework (Vue.js), implementing new standards for page rendering, and transitioning from a monolithic architecture to independently deployable microfrontends. These improvements aim to enhance application performance and user experience [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/senior-software-engineer-web-platform/92836).

# Additional Reading

- [ThousandEyes Developer Reference](https://developer.thousandeyes.com/)
- [ThousandEyes Status](https://status.thousandeyes.com/history)
- [ThousandEyes Documentation](https://docs.thousandeyes.com/)

ThousandEyes, as part of Cisco, is positioned as a leader in Digital Experience Assurance, with a robust platform that addresses the complexities of modern network environments. The company's commitment to innovation, integration within Cisco's ecosystem, and focus on diversity make it an attractive opportunity for prospective candidates and investors alike. The ongoing enhancements to its product offerings and the strategic direction under Cisco's leadership suggest a promising future for ThousandEyes in the digital experience monitoring space.

# Summary of ThousandEyes Webpages

## ThousandEyes Developer Reference
The ThousandEyes Developer Reference page is designed for developers looking to integrate or utilize ThousandEyes' network intelligence capabilities. However, it appears that JavaScript must be enabled in the browser to access the full content of the page.

## ThousandEyes Status
The ThousandEyes Status page provides real-time updates and historical data regarding the operational status of ThousandEyes services. Users can check for any outages, performance issues, or maintenance activities that may affect service availability.

## ThousandEyes Documentation
The documentation site for ThousandEyes serves as a comprehensive resource for users of the Cisco ThousandEyes network intelligence platform. It includes:

- **Customer Support**: Users can open support cases with the ThousandEyes Customer Engineering team for assistance.
- **ThousandEyes Platform**: A link to access the ThousandEyes platform directly.
- **ThousandEyes Blog**: A section dedicated to blog posts that may provide insights, updates, and best practices related to network intelligence.

## Conclusion
ThousandEyes offers a robust platform for network intelligence, with resources available for developers, real-time service status updates, and extensive documentation to support users.

## Bibliography
- [ThousandEyes Developer Reference](https://developer.thousandeyes.com/)
- [ThousandEyes Status](https://status.thousandeyes.com/history)
- [ThousandEyes Documentation](https://docs.thousandeyes.com/)

reviews.cons:
- Sometimes the lunches aren't very good
- You have to stay later on release days (every 2 weeks) so you can be available to fix any issues with your code. Usually about 
- There's an expectation that people are responsible for their own work, so you need to manage your time to ensure you can finish your tasks on time and don't over allocate yourself. 
- Not a lot of handholding which can be a problem for somebody that's not as independent
reviews.pros:
- Strong engineering culture that cares about doing things correctly and with quality instead of rushing out half-baked features
- Merit based, people who contribute significantly are fast tracked in the promotion/raise cycle.
- Employees are given a lot of ownership over the code, allowing them to make design/architectural decisions
- No micromanagement, a largely autonomous culture where you really can spend the majority of your time writing code
- Everyone has the opportunity to voice their opinion and get involved in the product management process or help shape  the technical direction of the product
- Great product that solves real problems
- The company has a solid business case and track record of growth
- Good work/life balance... people probably average 9 hours/day (except on release days)
- No arrogance policy, the company makes an effort to hire people who are pleasant to work with.
- Typical startup perks. Catered lunches every day,  stocked kitchen,  all types of coffee machines, medical/dental/vision premiums covered, unlimited leave policy

reviews.cons: There can be a lot of work at times
reviews.pros:
Great work environment 
Good Pay
Good Work Hours

reviews.advice: Don't lose sight of your core values that permeate through the company. Stay true to who ThousandEyes is. Keep investing in top talent and keeping them around in a hyper-competitive market.
reviews.cons: Some slight growing pains, but they mitigate the pains by great planning and execution. Can't ask for more.
reviews.pros:
ThousandEyes is way ahead of other start-ups that are around 250-300 Employees. I have worked for Tech Startups for the last 10 years, some of them fail, some of them flourish to the point of acquisition and a very few IPO. 

ThousandEyes is on its way! Humility will make you shine here, that is what it's all about! With great power, comes great responsibility! Everyone here is a superhero, a cohesive team lead by a down to earth visionaries (Our Founders.) The culture is not just unique, it is a competitive differentiator to attract and retain top talent in a candidate dominate recruiting market in SF. 

The product is game-changing, and the possibilities are endless to reach new verticals and untapped revenue streams. The perks and benes are top notch, they feed you, mix up happy hours, off-site events, etc... 

The average tenure of the Employees here is almost 3 years, very impressive and rare. ThousandEyes does things the right way, and it shows throughout the organization. Impressive Board Members, VC-backed by top-notch firms; you can't ask for more positive indicators of where this rocketship is going!
reviews.summary: Most mature Tech Startup I have worked for!

reviews.advice:
- Understand that you have a very small team. It is impossible to keep up with the scaling and product roadmap, the ongoing migrations and everything the Cisco acquisition involves.
- Be open and embrace the feedback you get. Upper management should genuinely care about this, not pretend like it does and then do nothing about it.
- Train your managers. It is extremely demotivating to work in an environment where your manager only cares about checking the OKR box at the end of the quarter and is completely disconnected from the team and its work.
reviews.cons:
- The engineering organization lacks transparency and there is a complete disconnect between management and individual contributors.
- Deadlines are either tight or straight unachievable, leading to poorly implemented and rushed features, and burnout across the board.
- Small teams and too many things to do. Constant context switching between tasks that show up unexpected.

This used to be a great company to work for, the earlier reviews in here are accurate. However, the environment in the engineering and operations department started deteriorating a couple of years ago and very little is left of what it used to be.

employerResponses.response: Thank you for taking the time to share your feedback with us. ThousandEyes strives to empower our leaders with tools and training to support our teammates. We acknowledge that we can always improve and need to continue to invest in our leaders.  We’ve shared this feedback with our senior leadership team and will align on the appropriate training to support an exceptional teammate experience. Please participate in our regular anonymous pulse checks so that we can continue to monitor the well-being of our teams. We encourage you to take advantage of these to share your feedback in real-time and provide us with the opportunity to make any needed changes.

reviews.pros:
- Modern tech stack.
- Product is used by top tier companies.
- Challenging scale, especially after the Cisco acquisition.

reviews.advice: Good communication is key to success in a growing company, ensuring that everyone who joins the company knows the core mission, and adheres to the same standards as everybody else is vital to continued success.
reviews.cons: There are never enough conference rooms, but that seems to be a problem everywhere.
reviews.pros:
This is an extremely open and collaborative organization where engineers are encouraged to take control of, and responsibility for their day-to-day tasks while still delivering a high-quality and valuable service to Customers. When problems are identified, the focus is on who is responsible to address them, rather than who is at fault.

The office is open, welcoming and always well-stocked with provisions. Lunch is provided daily and there are plenty facilities for team-building, including pool, ping-pong and video-games.

The platform itself is incredibly stable, and a consistent 2-week release-cycle means that bugs are fixed and features are added on a regular basis, which makes customers extremely happy.  Customer satisfaction and engagement rates are off the charts, and the live-chat support model is setting the standard for response & resolution times.

Best of all, this is a small company that is growing, so you are always going to be exposed to other areas of the business and have the opportunity to get involved in projects that span multiple departments. The opportunity to learn new skills and develop as an individual here is immense.

reviews.advice: Keep up the good work.  We are all working to accomplish the same goal, and fully support the vision.
reviews.cons: There really are not any cons I can think of.   ThousandEyes as a whole has met my needs as an employee.  From a business perspective, the management team has a clear vision as to where they want to go and they are making progress in that direction.
reviews.pros: ThousandEyes has been the best carrier move I have made.  The technology is exciting, and fills a huge gap in the market. The day-to-day work is enjoyable and fulfilling.  The entire team is amazing, and my immediate team is a collection of intelligent and fun individuals that make going to work everyday a pleasant and fun experience.  I really cannot say enough about how positive my experience has been.   Normally when I join a company, one year in I get bored and start looking for my next op, that has not been the case here, and that has never happened before.   The benefits are great, salary is competitive, and rewards/company events keep things interesting.
reviews.summary: The best team I've ever been a part of!

reviews.advice:
Start paying attention to your teams and make sure that all teams have the tools they need to get their jobs done efficiently. 
You stated in the beginning you would maintain the culture you had prior to the acquisition and yet only a few short months later it seems to have vanished.
reviews.cons:
Lack of the culture that made TE great.
Working for TE is basically working for Cisco and it seems to be more of an afterthought than an actual integrated company.
Upward trajectory is extremely limited in this BU unless you want to hop to other BUs or acquired companies (at least for IT).
Management seems to be either too busy or doesn't care to look into issues that come up and are repeatedly brought up.
Pay is low in comparison to other companies.
reviews.pros:
Most of the people who worked here prior to the acquisition are all very cool people that fit the culture that used to exist.
The sales are good and it doesn't seem to be slowing down.
reviews.summary: Was a really good company prior to the acquisition by Cisco.

reviews.cons: Even though I feel good about doing some small part to keep the Internet up and running, it's not always easy to show off my work! The product is quite technical, so it's not that easy to explain to people. But, like all ThousandEyes employees, I don't have a big ego, so that doesn't really bother me. ;) I find the work environment much more important to my happiness.
reviews.pros:
The culture at ThousandEyes is something really special. It's a culture of excellence without egos. Everyone at the company is motivated and top-notch, without exception, but everyone is also accessible, helpful, and open to feedback, without exception.

As an engineer, I also find the product really cool and fun to work on. It's really technically challenging, and it's rewarding to know the software we write is actually what the company is selling. So anything we do to improve the product or the user experience is really valued by the company and the users.

reviews.advice: Keep doing what you're doing. Seems to be working great!
reviews.cons:
It's difficult to think of cons. Anything I can think of is a very minor complaint.

- The onboarding process can be slightly improved, but in general is fine due to everyone being willing to help and answer any questions.
reviews.pros:
- Awesome Coworkers. Everyone is friendly, supportive, intelligent and fun to be around.
- High standard of code quality. A lot of effort is made to keep the code base clear and easy to maintain.
- Interesting product. The technology that we're developing is pretty cool and it has been exciting to watch it evolve.
- Growth. The company has a solid list of customers and is continuing to gain more and more momentum everyday.
- Supportive work environment. The company is supportive of the needs and personal growth of their employees and makes an effort to make sure everyone is happy and taken care of. There is a system of communication in place so you can relay any troubles your having to someone higher up.
reviews.summary: Love it here! Best company I ever worked for.

reviews.cons: Not for people who like huge companies with lots of red tape and politics.
reviews.pros: This company is FANTASTIC!  I have never seen an early stage company with such a well developed product and many amazing logos (that most early stage companies would die for!)  The company is backed by the great reputation of Sequoia and the product is designed by 2 innovative thought leaders Mohit Lad and Ricardo Oliveira, both hold PhD's from UCLA.  They have taken an unique approach to performance management for the cloud era that is quickly embraced by customers and prospects.  The office is in downtown San Francisco with views of the bay bridge, daily catered lunches, free gym memberships and in office massages (amazing perks!) This organization values all employees and is eager to provide resources to promote continuous learning and growth.  Mohit and Ricardo have done a fantastic job in carefully selecting first employees with high aptitude and great attitudes to ensure that the organization can properly scale.

reviews.advice:
* Make a stronger push for data collection & data-driven decision making across teams

* Streamline and communicate career growth pathways (e.g. how to get promoted, how to transition across teams, how to track work output weekly - monthly - yearly)

* Keep the company culture alive!  I've heard complaints from a few new employees that they are not getting their own superheros... this would be a shame not to continue.
reviews.cons:
- The path to promotions has never been clearly defined, even less so now after the Cisco acquisition

- Hiring and recruiting efforts have not been given enough resources since the Cisco acquisition

- There is a lot of inertia within the broader engineering organization w.r.t. adopting newer tools
reviews.pros:
+ Cisco acquisition has (so far) kept the original business and team structure entirely intact, with the goal of keeping ThousandEyes as an independent business unit

+ The product is deeply technical, and has a humongous moat from competition; especially now that we ship ThousandEyes software in Cisco switches and have access to Cisco's sales channel. This equates to fat bonuses!

+ The engineering team is full of smart, experienced people; there is a strong "no jerks" rule when hiring.

+ Most of our production services are deployed in Kubernetes

+ The company culture is supportive, progressive, and light-hearted (Mohit is always telling dad-jokes in all-hands meetings, veteran engineers get their own bobble-head figurines, every engineer picks a superhero to be their avatar)

+ The pay is top-notch: San Francisco-level salary + equity, but in Texas

+ Strong commitment to mental health & work-life balance
reviews.summary: Smart People, Strong Product, Fun Culture - with Growing Pains

reviews.advice: Get the Austin office culture under control.  Don't hire on SDRs to cover territories that are completely untouched and expect them to break into 10 new logos a month. Learn to develop employees instead of burn and churn.
reviews.cons: I saw this company lay off/ fire so many employees without a warning, probation plan, or notice.   This is probably why you can hardly find an employee who has been there for 2 years!  Our quotas would sometimes not be provided to us until the last week of the month.  The work environment is unprofessional and at sometimes, downright hostile.  The on-boarding training was sub par.  Sales numbers are declining across.   In 7 months I was asked to take on multiple roles on the team.  I was even asked to develop a sales territory via cold outbound prospecting which had no Account Executives hired to take meetings. The next career step was Corporate Sales and their manager was in the office maybe two days a week.  The SDR team is incredibly negative and sometimes personally insulting.  The new SDR manager is trying to change this, but I fear the momentum is too much.

employerResponses.response:
Hello,

We want every employee to have a great experience at ThousandEyes and wish we could have made your experience better. There are a few items we wish to highlight: 1) Many of our sales hires in Austin are new because the decision to start a customer centric hub in Austin was made just over a year ago. 2) Employees go through performance reviews and feedback. These HR conversations are confidential. 3) We are proud of the work being done by the SDR team and have invested in employee development with many examples of promotions from the SDR team to the Corporate Sales team and onwards as well as a recent change in sales model so CSR teams get the ability to partner with more experienced field sales teams. 4) The company is continuing to experience healthy growth driven by customer revenues.

We understand ThousandEyes may not be a fit for everybody. We appreciate your feedback and will continue working on creating a positive experience for everyone.

Doug Cunningham
Manager, Enterprise Sales Development

- Awesome Coworkers. Everyone is friendly, supportive, intelligent and fun to be around.
- High standard of code quality. A lot of effort is made to keep the code base clear and easy to maintain.
- Interesting product. The technology that we're developing is pretty cool and it has been exciting to watch it evolve.
- Growth. The company has a solid list of customers and is continuing to gain more and more momentum everyday.
- Supportive work environment. The company is supportive of the needs and personal growth of their employees and makes an effort to make sure everyone is happy and taken care of. There is a system of communication in place so you can relay any troubles your having to someone higher up.
reviews.summary: Love it here! Best company I ever worked for.

reviews.advice: Get the Austin office culture under control.  Don't hire on SDRs to cover territories that are completely untouched and expect them to break into 10 new logos a month. Learn to develop employees instead of burn and churn.
reviews.cons: I saw this company lay off/ fire so many employees without a warning, probation plan, or notice.   This is probably why you can hardly find an employee who has been there for 2 years!  Our quotas would sometimes not be provided to us until the last week of the month.  The work environment is unprofessional and at sometimes, downright hostile.  The on-boarding training was sub par.  Sales numbers are declining across.   In 7 months I was asked to take on multiple roles on the team.  I was even asked to develop a sales territory via cold outbound prospecting which had no Account Executives hired to take meetings. The next career step was Corporate Sales and their manager was in the office maybe two days a week.  The SDR team is incredibly negative and sometimes personally insulting.  The new SDR manager is trying to change this, but I fear the momentum is too much.
reviews.pros: Great benefits, lunch provided, snacks, good base salary, cool office, great product, new SDR manager is a great guy and mentor

reviews.cons:
- Sometimes the lunches aren't very good
- You have to stay later on release days (every 2 weeks) so you can be available to fix any issues with your code. Usually about 
- There's an expectation that people are responsible for their own work, so you need to manage your time to ensure you can finish your tasks on time and don't over allocate yourself. 
- Not a lot of handholding which can be a problem for somebody that's not as independent
reviews.pros:
- Strong engineering culture that cares about doing things correctly and with quality instead of rushing out half-baked features
- Merit based, people who contribute significantly are fast tracked in the promotion/raise cycle.
- Employees are given a lot of ownership over the code, allowing them to make design/architectural decisions
- No micromanagement, a largely autonomous culture where you really can spend the majority of your time writing code
- Everyone has the opportunity to voice their opinion and get involved in the product management process or help shape  the technical direction of the product
- Great product that solves real problems
- The company has a solid business case and track record of growth
- Good work/life balance... people probably average 9 hours/day (except on release days)
- No arrogance policy, the company makes an effort to hire people who are pleasant to work with.
- Typical startup perks. Catered lunches every day,  stocked kitchen,  all types of coffee machines, medical/dental/vision premiums covered, unlimited leave policy

reviews.advice: Good communication is key to success in a growing company, ensuring that everyone who joins the company knows the core mission, and adheres to the same standards as everybody else is vital to continued success.
reviews.cons: There are never enough conference rooms, but that seems to be a problem everywhere.
reviews.pros:
This is an extremely open and collaborative organization where engineers are encouraged to take control of, and responsibility for their day-to-day tasks while still delivering a high-quality and valuable service to Customers. When problems are identified, the focus is on who is responsible to address them, rather than who is at fault.

The office is open, welcoming and always well-stocked with provisions. Lunch is provided daily and there are plenty facilities for team-building, including pool, ping-pong and video-games.

The platform itself is incredibly stable, and a consistent 2-week release-cycle means that bugs are fixed and features are added on a regular basis, which makes customers extremely happy.  Customer satisfaction and engagement rates are off the charts, and the live-chat support model is setting the standard for response & resolution times.

Best of all, this is a small company that is growing, so you are always going to be exposed to other areas of the business and have the opportunity to get involved in projects that span multiple departments. The opportunity to learn new skills and develop as an individual here is immense.

reviews.advice: Keep up the good work.  We are all working to accomplish the same goal, and fully support the vision.
reviews.cons: There really are not any cons I can think of.   ThousandEyes as a whole has met my needs as an employee.  From a business perspective, the management team has a clear vision as to where they want to go and they are making progress in that direction.
reviews.pros: ThousandEyes has been the best carrier move I have made.  The technology is exciting, and fills a huge gap in the market. The day-to-day work is enjoyable and fulfilling.  The entire team is amazing, and my immediate team is a collection of intelligent and fun individuals that make going to work everyday a pleasant and fun experience.  I really cannot say enough about how positive my experience has been.   Normally when I join a company, one year in I get bored and start looking for my next op, that has not been the case here, and that has never happened before.   The benefits are great, salary is competitive, and rewards/company events keep things interesting.
reviews.summary: The best team I've ever been a part of!

reviews.advice: Don't lose sight of your core values that permeate through the company. Stay true to who ThousandEyes is. Keep investing in top talent and keeping them around in a hyper-competitive market.
reviews.cons: Some slight growing pains, but they mitigate the pains by great planning and execution. Can't ask for more.
reviews.pros:
ThousandEyes is way ahead of other start-ups that are around 250-300 Employees. I have worked for Tech Startups for the last 10 years, some of them fail, some of them flourish to the point of acquisition and a very few IPO. 

ThousandEyes is on its way! Humility will make you shine here, that is what it's all about! With great power, comes great responsibility! Everyone here is a superhero, a cohesive team lead by a down to earth visionaries (Our Founders.) The culture is not just unique, it is a competitive differentiator to attract and retain top talent in a candidate dominate recruiting market in SF. 

The product is game-changing, and the possibilities are endless to reach new verticals and untapped revenue streams. The perks and benes are top notch, they feed you, mix up happy hours, off-site events, etc... 

The average tenure of the Employees here is almost 3 years, very impressive and rare. ThousandEyes does things the right way, and it shows throughout the organization. Impressive Board Members, VC-backed by top-notch firms; you can't ask for more positive indicators of where this rocketship is going!
reviews.summary: Most mature Tech Startup I have worked for!

reviews.advice:
- Understand that you have a very small team. It is impossible to keep up with the scaling and product roadmap, the ongoing migrations and everything the Cisco acquisition involves.
- Be open and embrace the feedback you get. Upper management should genuinely care about this, not pretend like it does and then do nothing about it.
- Train your managers. It is extremely demotivating to work in an environment where your manager only cares about checking the OKR box at the end of the quarter and is completely disconnected from the team and its work.
reviews.cons:
- The engineering organization lacks transparency and there is a complete disconnect between management and individual contributors.
- Deadlines are either tight or straight unachievable, leading to poorly implemented and rushed features, and burnout across the board.
- Small teams and too many things to do. Constant context switching between tasks that show up unexpected.

This used to be a great company to work for, the earlier reviews in here are accurate. However, the environment in the engineering and operations department started deteriorating a couple of years ago and very little is left of what it used to be.
reviews.pros:
- Modern tech stack.
- Product is used by top tier companies.
- Challenging scale, especially after the Cisco acquisition.

reviews.advice:
Start paying attention to your teams and make sure that all teams have the tools they need to get their jobs done efficiently. 
You stated in the beginning you would maintain the culture you had prior to the acquisition and yet only a few short months later it seems to have vanished.
reviews.cons:
Lack of the culture that made TE great.
Working for TE is basically working for Cisco and it seems to be more of an afterthought than an actual integrated company.
Upward trajectory is extremely limited in this BU unless you want to hop to other BUs or acquired companies (at least for IT).
Management seems to be either too busy or doesn't care to look into issues that come up and are repeatedly brought up.
Pay is low in comparison to other companies.
reviews.pros:
Most of the people who worked here prior to the acquisition are all very cool people that fit the culture that used to exist.
The sales are good and it doesn't seem to be slowing down.
reviews.summary: Was a really good company prior to the acquisition by Cisco.

reviews.advice:
* Make a stronger push for data collection & data-driven decision making across teams

* Streamline and communicate career growth pathways (e.g. how to get promoted, how to transition across teams, how to track work output weekly - monthly - yearly)

* Keep the company culture alive!  I've heard complaints from a few new employees that they are not getting their own superheros... this would be a shame not to continue.
reviews.cons:
- The path to promotions has never been clearly defined, even less so now after the Cisco acquisition

- Hiring and recruiting efforts have not been given enough resources since the Cisco acquisition

- There is a lot of inertia within the broader engineering organization w.r.t. adopting newer tools
reviews.pros:
+ Cisco acquisition has (so far) kept the original business and team structure entirely intact, with the goal of keeping ThousandEyes as an independent business unit

+ The product is deeply technical, and has a humongous moat from competition; especially now that we ship ThousandEyes software in Cisco switches and have access to Cisco's sales channel. This equates to fat bonuses!

+ The engineering team is full of smart, experienced people; there is a strong "no jerks" rule when hiring.

+ Most of our production services are deployed in Kubernetes

+ The company culture is supportive, progressive, and light-hearted (Mohit is always telling dad-jokes in all-hands meetings, veteran engineers get their own bobble-head figurines, every engineer picks a superhero to be their avatar)

+ The pay is top-notch: San Francisco-level salary + equity, but in Texas

+ Strong commitment to mental health & work-life balance
reviews.summary: Smart People, Strong Product, Fun Culture - with Growing Pains
A mediocre tech environment with startup spirit but no startup prospects

Managers are not good at all - I deducted 2 stars because I felt my managers had a hands-off approach. They didn't offer timely feedback, resulting in misunderstandings and frustration, and I believe it hindered chances for improvement. 
Additionally, there was no intern experience within their team, and they expected the intern to grasp a complex application quickly. 
The feedback provided during the exit interview wasn't constructive, leaving me feeling disheartened. I consistently sought ways to improve every week but received no opinions or feedback during that time and it was all thrown at the end.

My teammates were great, I learned a lot from them, and they always stood by me and encouraged me.

# ThousandEyes (part of Cisco) Glassdoor Review Quotes

## 1. Reasons Employees Like Working for ThousandEyes

- "This company is FANTASTIC! ... The office is in downtown San Francisco with views of the bay bridge, daily catered lunches, free gym memberships and in office massages (amazing perks!)" [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2013-10-15)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW3184365.htm)
  
- "The culture at ThousandEyes is something really special. It's a culture of excellence without egos." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2017-04-19)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW14701963.htm)

- "Awesome Coworkers. Everyone is friendly, supportive, intelligent and fun to be around." [(Software Engineer, Glassdoor, 2017-05-01)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW14867400.htm)

- "ThousandEyes has been the best career move I have made. The technology is exciting, and fills a huge gap in the market." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2018-05-23)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW20716546.htm)

- "ThousandEyes is way ahead of other start-ups... The product is game-changing, and the possibilities are endless." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2019-04-25)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW25843176.htm)

- "Great work environment... Great place to learn and grow at." [(Network Support Engineer, Glassdoor, 2023-08-16)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW79211598.htm)

## 2. Reasons Employees Dislike Working for ThousandEyes

- "I saw this company lay off/fire so many employees without a warning... The work environment is unprofessional and at times, downright hostile." [(Sales Development Representative, Glassdoor, 2017-08-25)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW16530380.htm)

- "The engineering organization lacks transparency and there is a complete disconnect between management and individual contributors." [(Software Engineer, Glassdoor, 2021-04-19)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW45744595.htm)

- "Working for TE is basically working for Cisco and it seems to be more of an afterthought than an actual integrated company." [(IT Engineer, Glassdoor, 2021-05-07)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW46632030.htm)

- "With the company now just a division of Cisco, the cash compensation is at not very competitive level compared to more established companies in the Valley." [(Software Engineer, Glassdoor, 2022-02-02)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW59014692.htm)

- "There can be a lot of work at times." [(Software Engineer, Glassdoor, 2022-03-11)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW61013671.htm)

## 3. Key Events or Changes in the Company

- "The product is deeply technical, and has a humongous moat from competition; especially now that we ship ThousandEyes software in Cisco switches." [(Software Engineer II, Glassdoor, 2021-05-20)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW47223951.htm)

- "ThousandEyes still positions itself as a 'start-up' despite it being acquired by Cisco." [(Software Engineer, Glassdoor, 2022-02-02)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW59014692.htm)

- "Cisco slows the BU down." [(Sales Director, Glassdoor, 2022-08-02)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW67435456.htm)

- "The path to promotions has never been clearly defined, even less so now after the Cisco acquisition." [(Software Engineer II, Glassdoor, 2021-05-20)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW47223951.htm)

## 4. Verifiable Facts About Working at ThousandEyes

- "The company has a solid business case and track record of growth." [(Software Engineer, Glassdoor, 2018-01-15)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW18744675.htm)

- "The average tenure of the Employees here is almost 3 years, very impressive and rare." [(Anonymous, Glassdoor, 2019-04-25)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW25843176.htm)

- "Great benefits, lunch provided, snacks, good base salary, cool office, great product." [(Sales Development Representative, Glassdoor, 2017-08-25)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW16530380.htm)

- "The company culture is truly outstanding—it's inclusive, supportive, and fosters a spirit of innovation." [(Implementation Engineer, Glassdoor, 2024-10-04)](https://www.glassdoor.com/Reviews/Employee-Review-ThousandEyes-RVW91629651.htm)

This organized list captures the sentiments and experiences of employees at ThousandEyes, reflecting both positive and negative aspects of working at the company, as well as key changes and verifiable facts.

# [ThousandEyes (part of Cisco) Seattle Office: Careers, Perks + Culture](https://www.builtinseattle.com/company/thousandeyes-part-cisco)
As of August 7, 2020, ThousandEyes is a part of Cisco (NASDAQ: CSCO).

ThousandEyes delivers visibility into digital experiences delivered over the Internet. The world’s largest companies rely on our platform, collective intelligence and smart monitoring agents to get a real-time map of how their customers and employees reach and experience critical apps and services across traditional, SD-WAN, Internet and cloud provider networks. ThousandEyes is used by some of the world’s largest and fastest growing brands, including more than 100 of the Fortune 500, 190 of the Global 2000, 6 of the 7 top US banks, and 9 of the top 10 global software companies.

# [SparkCognition Austin Office: Careers, Perks + Culture](https://www.builtinaustin.com/company/sparkcognition?ref=levels.fyi&utm_source=levels.fyi)
SparkCognition’s award-winning AI solutions predict future outcomes, prescribe next best actions, and help ensure worker safety. We partner with the world’s industry leaders to analyze, optimize, and learn from all types of data, augment human intelligence, drive profitable growth, and achieve operational excellence.

Our patented AI technologies, including machine learning, deep neural networks, natural language processing, and computer vision lead the industry in innovation and help accelerate digital transformation. Our solutions allow organizations to solve critical problems – prevent unexpected downtime, maximize asset performance, deliver net-zero initiatives, and eliminate accidents, all while avoiding zero-day cyberattacks.

SparkCognition’s products enable organizations to quickly capitalize on their data to provide real-time actionable insights, amplify their return on investment, and redefine best practices. Since inception, we have worked toward perfecting AI to accelerate market adoption and enhance, advance, and safeguard organizations, fostering a smarter, safer, and more sustainable future. To learn more, visit www.sparkcognition.com.

# [Senior Software Engineer, Web Platform - ThousandEyes (part of Cisco)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/senior-software-engineer-web-platform/92836)
Who We Are

Cisco ThousandEyes is a Digital Experience Assurance platform that empowers organizations to deliver flawless digital experiences across every network – even the ones they don’t own. Powered by AI and an unmatched set of cloud, internet and enterprise network telemetry data, ThousandEyes enables IT teams to proactively detect, diagnose, and remediate issues – before they impact end- user experiences.

ThousandEyes is deeply integrated across the entire Cisco technology portfolio and beyond, helping customers deploy at scale while also delivering AI-powered assurance insights within Cisco’s leading Networking, Security, Collaboration, and Observability portfolios.

About the Role

The Web Platform team is passionate about building common abstractions that are shared by the various ThousandEyes development teams. Our mission is to evangelize standards, patterns, and best practices for software design and development at ThousandEyes. This is a frontend-leaning software development engineering role focused on platform-wide development, where you’ll work on the underpinnings of our web application to ensure that it runs smoothly for our end users and is intuitive to build for other ThousandEyes developers. We value engineers who have an excitement for learning new skills, an eagerness to venture into unknown problem spaces, and a keen ability to identify and correct problems as they encounter them. Web Platform developers maintain flexible skill sets and growth mindsets, as we’re often tagged to assist with a variety of topics within the wide-spanning layer supporting all web application architecture at ThousandEyes.

Lately, we’ve worked on impactful projects such as:

Upgrading the version of our core frontend framework (Vue.js) across all services

Modernizing and setting new standards for page rendering strategy

Splitting the ThousandEyes core monolith into independently deployable microfrontends

Migrating and upgrading core JavaScript utilities, mitigating potential security vulnerabilities

Improving application-wide UI elements such as our menus, support chat, and customer satisfaction surveys

What You’ll Do

Improving the core frontend technology that enables the ThousandEyes engineering organization to scale and keeps developers happy, including build processes and test frameworks

Evangelizing modern frontend architecture and development best practices, raising the bar for frontend development at ThousandEyes through implementation, presentations, and documentation

Boosting our application’s web performance, tracking core web vitals

Exploring new technologies that will benefit our workflow and sharing comprehensive opinions on architectural/technical decisions

Providing support to other engineers on the team and throughout the engineering organization as they build upon our team’s work to achieve their goals

Qualifications

Experience with modern frontend frameworks/libraries and knowledge of the differences between them (e.g. Vue, React, Angular, etc)

Experience with Java, Golang or similar programming languages.

Comfortable digging deep to solve problems, prototyping solutions, and exploring new technologies and architectural patterns.

Ability to advocate for frontend development best practices and improve the frontend stack across an engineering organization

Proven track record of identifying problems, proposing and selecting solutions, and executing them effectively

Comfortable collaborating, communicating, and driving change across multiple Engineering teams

Passion for sharing ideas, bringing others along, caring for teammates, and attracting other great developers to join our growing organization

Cisco values the perspectives and skills that emerge from employees with diverse backgrounds. That's why Cisco is expanding the boundaries of discovering top talent by not only focusing on candidates with educational degrees and experience but also placing more emphasis on unlocking potential. We believe that everyone has something to offer and that diverse teams are better equipped to solve problems, innovate, and create a positive impact.

We encourage you to apply even if you do not believe you meet every single qualification. Not all strong candidates will meet every single qualification. Research shows that people from underrepresented groups are more prone to experiencing imposter syndrome and doubting the strength of their candidacy. We urge you not to prematurely exclude yourself and to apply if you're interested in this work.

Cisco is an Affirmative Action and Equal Opportunity Employer and all qualified applicants will receive consideration for employment without regard to race, color, religion, gender, sexual orientation, national origin, genetic information, age, disability, veteran status, or any other legally protected basis. Cisco will consider for employment, on a case by case basis, qualified applicants with arrest and conviction records.

US – COMPENSATION RANGE – MESSAGE TO APPLICANTS

# [Engineering Manager, Site Reliability Engineering (FedRAMP) - ThousandEyes (part of Cisco)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/engineering-manager-site-reliability-engineering-fedramp/81284)
Who We Are

The name ThousandEyes was born from two big ideas: the power to see things not ordinarily possible and the ability to collect insights from a multitude of vantage points. As the world continues its digital transformation and relies more on cloud services and the Internet, the “network,” which is now both public and private, has become a black box our customers cannot see or understand.

Our Internet and cloud intelligence platform delivers the only collectively powered real-time view of the Internet and private networks, cloud, and SaaS platforms, helping enterprises and service providers identify problems before they impact revenue, damage brand reputation, or halt employee productivity.

In August 2020, Cisco Systems completed the acquisition of ThousandEyes, which now forms the ThousandEyes Business Unit within the Cisco Networking Business Group and is the Network Assurance solution for Cisco across the Cisco Networking Cloud and Cisco Security Cloud. ThousandEyes is also a foundational component of Cisco’s growing Full-Stack Observability (“FSO”) business.

The successful applicant will be performing work in FedRAMP environments, and therefore, must be a U.S. Person (i.e. U.S. citizen, U.S. national, lawful permanent resident, asylee, or refugee). This position may also perform work that the U.S. government has specified can only be performed by a U.S. citizen on U.S. soil.

About the role

This role is the Site Reliability Engineering Manager for the FedRAMP SRE team at ThousandEyes.

The FedRAMP SRE team is focused on our Federal region’s platform. The team is responsible for all aspects of the Federal region’s infrastructure and operations, such as availability, latency, performance, efficiency, change management, monitoring, emergency response, and capacity planning, with a strong focus on security.

What You'll Do

Lead and inspire a talented SRE team, fostering a culture of innovation, collaboration, and excellence

Drive the strategic vision for build, implementation, and management of FedRAMP-compliant infrastructure and systems.

Collaborate closely with cross-functional teams, including development, product management and security to define and implement FedRAMP-compliant processes and strategies.

Provide oversight and direction for how ThousandEyes approaches the continuous monitoring, logging, and auditing of systems to ensure compliance with FedRAMP controls.

Stay current with industry best practices, evolving security threats, and updates to FedRAMP guidelines, and apply this knowledge to enhance the security posture of our platform and systems.

Drive operational excellence in operations and security processes.

Leverage synergies with Cisco's broader ecosystem, collaborating with counterparts on FedRAMP.

Mentor and develop engineering talent, fostering a culture of continuous learning and professional growth within the FedRAMP SRE team.

Qualifications

You have led a team of 4+ engineers

You have a total of 5+ years of experience building and supporting missing critical services with focus on automation, availability and performance

Experience building and/or operating FedRAMP environments.

Experience identifying and analyzing cyber security risks.

Strong understanding of the FedRAMP framework, its controls, and compliance requirements.

Familiarity with security best practices, vulnerability management, and incident response processes.

Can provide strong technical vision for your team and ensure consistent delivery on objectives

Have experience formulating a team's technical strategy and roadmap; you've collaborated and partnered effectively with several other teams to execute on shared goals

You have worked on large-scale distributed systems including multi-tiered architecture

Understand how to balance tactical needs with strategic growth and quality-based initiatives that can span multiple quarters

# Comprehensive Analyst Report on ThousandEyes (part of Cisco)

## Company Overview
ThousandEyes, acquired by Cisco in August 2020, operates as a part of Cisco's Networking Business Group. The company specializes in Digital Experience Assurance, providing visibility into digital experiences delivered over the Internet. Its platform is utilized by over 100 of the Fortune 500 companies and 190 of the Global 2000, including six of the seven top US banks and nine of the top ten global software companies [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/company/thousandeyes-part-cisco).

## Product Overview
ThousandEyes offers a comprehensive platform that empowers organizations to monitor and enhance digital experiences across various networks, including traditional, SD-WAN, Internet, and cloud provider networks. The platform leverages AI and extensive telemetry data to help IT teams proactively detect, diagnose, and resolve issues before they impact end-user experiences [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/senior-software-engineer-web-platform/92836).

## Recent Developments
### Acquisitions and Integrations
Following its acquisition by Cisco, ThousandEyes has been integrated into Cisco's broader technology portfolio, enhancing its capabilities in network assurance and observability. It is now a foundational component of Cisco's Full-Stack Observability business, which aims to provide comprehensive insights across networking and security domains [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/engineering-manager-site-reliability-engineering-fedramp/81284).

### Product Enhancements
ThousandEyes has been actively modernizing its technology stack. Recent projects include upgrading its core frontend framework (Vue.js), implementing new standards for page rendering, and transitioning from a monolithic architecture to independently deployable microfrontends. These improvements aim to enhance application performance and user experience [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/senior-software-engineer-web-platform/92836).

## Company Scale and Workforce
While specific employee numbers post-acquisition are not disclosed, ThousandEyes is part of Cisco, which employs over 77,000 people globally. The integration into Cisco's ecosystem allows ThousandEyes to leverage Cisco's extensive resources and market reach [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/company/thousandeyes-part-cisco).

## Executive Insights
Cisco emphasizes the importance of diversity and inclusion within its workforce. The company encourages candidates from various backgrounds to apply, highlighting that diverse teams are better equipped to innovate and solve problems [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/senior-software-engineer-web-platform/92836). This approach is indicative of Cisco's broader corporate culture, which values diverse perspectives in driving business success.

## Financial and Employment Opportunities
ThousandEyes offers competitive compensation packages, with salary ranges for various roles reflecting the projected hiring range for new hires in the U.S. For example, software engineering roles can expect salaries ranging from $137,900 to $203,100, while principal software engineers may earn between $182,400 and $323,500, excluding equity and benefits [(Built In Seattle, 2020)](https://www.builtinseattle.com/job/senior-software-engineer-web-platform/92836).

## Conclusion
ThousandEyes, as part of Cisco, is positioned as a leader in Digital Experience Assurance, with a robust platform that addresses the complexities of modern network environments. The company's commitment to innovation, integration within Cisco's ecosystem, and focus on diversity make it an attractive opportunity for prospective candidates and investors alike. The ongoing enhancements to its product offerings and the strategic direction under Cisco's leadership suggest a promising future for ThousandEyes in the digital experience monitoring space.
